FacilityName: Royal Ridge Fruit and Cold Storage LLC.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP PROGRAM



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



A.Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response

Royal Ridge Fruit and Cold Storage (RR) accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  It is the policy of RR to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.



RR refrigeration personnel do respond to ammonia releases less than 300ppm and have received training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, in addition to training specifically for ammonia.  An emergency plan has been developed covering notification to public safety agencies and the public.  An evacuation plan for the plant has also been developed and all employees receive initial hire and yearly refresher training on this plan.



At RR anhydrous ammonia is used on-site. Ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance (EHS) list.  Chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:



Prevent unnecessary human exposure to the EHS

Reduce the threat of exposure to our personnel

Reduce the threat to the community and the surrounding ecosystem



B.Facility and Regulated Substance Handled



RR is a fruit processing and cold storage facility, located approximately one mile south-south east of Royal City, which is located in Grant county and within the state of Washington.



The regulated substance used at RR is anhydrous ammonia.  Chemical Abstract Number (CAS) # 7664-41-7.  The substance is used as a refrigerant. There is approximately 17,176 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the system as of this revision.  



RR uses other hazardous substances on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.  However, RR believes in the concept set forth in the General Duty Clause of the Clean Air Act.  To this effect, RR plans to established policies, procedure

s and training to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous substance release for the safety of its employees and surrounding areas.

C.Worst-Case and Alternative Scenarios



The off-site consequence analysis considers two ammonia release scenarios identified as worst case and alternative scenarios.  The worst case scenario is defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), which states that the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released.  The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst case scenario.



Worst-Case Scenario - Failure of the largest vessel would release 14,461 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The release would occur inside the compressor room; its walls are in direct contact with the outside, however the effects of building mitigation were not considered.  



The distance to the toxic end-point of 0.14 mg/L is .3 miles.  The risk radius extends past the boundaries of the plant, into public receptor areas. Distance was determined by use of RMP-COMP version 1.07.



Alternative Release Scenario  Several alternative scenarios were modeled, using ALOHA, version 5.3, however a release from the bottom (liquid space) of the receiver, under normal operating conditions, was chosen.  This alternative scenario provided the greatest risk radius of .2 miles.  There was no building mitigation used for this scenario.  It was, however, assumed that the safeties and computer control would limit the release to the amount in the receiver.



Both the worst-case and alternative scenarios are unlikely due to the safeties on the system such as temperature and pressure cutouts, computer controls and pressure relief valves to prevent an over pressure situation.



A more realistic scenario would be that of a pressure relief valve lifting, discharging ammonia vapor from vents on top of the building, approximately 40 feet above the ground.  In scenarios modeled for this type of an event, the risk

radius was reduced to approximately 325 feet. 



D.General Accidental Release Prevention Program



RRs accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:



Initial and continued training of personnel

Preventative maintenance programs as described in the PSM

Use of safety equipment and procedures

Use of accurate and effective written operating procedures



RR complies with:



OSHAs and Washington States process safety management rules.

Washington States General Safety and Health Codes.

Various Consensus Standards applicable to Ammonia Refrigeration.



The ammonia refrigeration system was installed by Double Kold of Yakima Washington and was built to standards and local codes at the time of installation.  Piping and equipment is secured and protected; compressor (engine) room doors are tight fitting and open outwards.  Other safety systems RR utilizes include:



Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely from a company laptop-modem system or from the manufacturers location in Yakima

Suction trap hi-level float

High discharge pressure shut down

Low suction pressure shut down

High discharge temperature shut down

Oil pressure failure shut down

High amperes shut down

Automatic timer to prevent short cycling via computer controls

Oil filters plugged shut down

250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent over pressure situations

150 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent over pressure situations

100 psi liquid relief valves on liquid line, to prevent over pressure situations

75 psi liquid relief valves on liquid line, to prevent over pressure situations

Operating Procedures and checklists have been prepared by RR to be used by employees performing operational functions.  Procedures are kept in the refrigeration managers office.  These procedures include: 



Pre-Start Up Procedures

Routine Operations

Maintenance

Response to major and minor releases

Emergency Action Plan



E.Five-Year

Accident History



RR has never had any accidents involving ammonia or any other hazardous chemical. 



F.Emergency Response Program



In addition to the operating procedures, RR has established Emergency Response Guidelines for releases involving ammonia.  These procedures are part of the ongoing training.



RR coordinates its response efforts with Grant County Fire District #10, which is the closest fire department.



Planned Safety Improvements



Since the last RMP, RR added 64,000 square feet of freezer and storage area to its initial facility.  This new structure is connected to the computerized monitoring and control systems.  All safety components of this system were incorporated into the construction.  



Additionally, a floor heating system was installed as part of the projects freezer room.  Heating the floor keeps the soil below, thawed during the winter and reduces the possibility of frost heave and thus potential damage to the Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) piping that is anchored to the floor.
